awd_titl_txt: ISS:   Unmasking contact-line mobility for Inertial Spreading using Drop Vibration and Coalescence
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Steen, Paul
Proposal Number: 1637960

The proposed research is focused on the study of the behavior of drops pinned on a surface that vibrates. The proposal is about developing a theory to predict the drop oscillation modes and the mobilization of the drop, while conducting very careful experiments to verify the theoretical findings at microgravity conditions. The advantage of conducting experiments at the International Space Station (ISS) is to focus on cases that are affected by gravity.  Results from this work can have applications on Earth in medical, manufacturing, industrial and agricultural processes.   For example, one of these processes is immersion lithography - an important technique that has allowed for down-scaling in semiconductor chip manufacturing processes. Results for the proposed work could improve the process of inertial spreading, a fundamental component in immersion lithography, and reduce defects found on semiconductor manufacturing by 10% over current standards. This can potentially lead to cost savings on the order of 10% in the semiconductor industry, which is already worth several hundred billion dollars annually.

Features of contact line motions that are small-scale and fast on Earth become larger and slower on the ISS, making them accessible to optical imaging there. ISS experiments are proposed to study inertial spreading. Inertial spreading is vitally important to manufacturing, coating and forming operations on Earth but challenging to study and has received less attention than viscous spreading. The experiments proposed will enable a contact line mobility parameter to be estimated. Two setups are envisioned. The first will periodically force the contact line motion of a substrate-attached drop using a mechanical shaker that drives plane normal oscillations. Using an electrowetting-based trigger, the second setup will induce a transient droplet-droplet coalescence event with consequent large sweeping by contact lines. Mobility is a material-like phenomenological parameter that captures out-of-equilibrium dynamical responses of a moving contact line. Once measured, the idea is that mobility can be used in predictions of inertial spreading in other situations. Shaker and sweeping experiments represent forced and transient contact line motions, respectively, and will demonstrate the utility of the mobility parameter. Predictions for mobile contact lines have received limited testing because contact line speeds are fast with small scale features of importance. The ISS will unmask these features and enable testing of a high-level theory of mobility of inertially-spreading contact lines. To the extent that the theory has rather striking parallels to the harmonic oscillator, to the Schroedinger equation and to the periodic table, educational impact to a broad group of students and public will accrue. Moreover, experiments can be phrased as a quest for "motion elements" using the metaphor with the periodic table of the chemical elements. The proposed education plan will teach graduate women to be competent technical leaders through the development of an outreach module that integrates the themes of the research conducted here to high school students. The long-term impact is to broaden the participation of women in STEM by developing their professional and mentoring skills, and empowering more women to pursue advanced career goals as postgraduates. A secondary impact is to continue to encourage young girls to pursue science and math in high school so that they are well-prepared and motivated to choose scientific majors in college.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Inertial or rapid spreading of liquids across solid surfaces occurs in silicon chip fabrication, 3D additive manufacturing, condensation heat transfer and other application areas. It is ubiquitous in engineering processes, but poorly understood, due largely to the rapid speed and small size of these dynamics on earth. The ISS provides larger length scales and slow time scales for inertial spreading dynamics because of the reduction of gravity. During this project, we carried out studies of drop motion on the ISS and carried out analysis of those motions from the data collected on the ISS. Two suites of experiments were proposed and conducted aboard the ISS: 1) A water drop was placed on a surface with particular wetting conditions and subjected to periodic vibration. The surface oscillated in the plane-normal direction at varying frequencies. Droplet response was filmed and the characteristics of the droplet response at particular frequencies were classified according to a recent theoretical prediction. Until now, these predictions had not been experimentally verified, due largely to terrestrial limitations of which the ISS is free from. Comparison to theory required the measurement of a mobility parameter M, a property that is difficult to measure on earth but accessible aboard the ISS. Excellent agreement was found among theory and experiments for a myriad of resonant frequencies over several different surfaces. 2)  A water drop was placed on a surface and a n adjacent drop was grown near the pre-positioned drop until the two drops coalesced. Upon coalescence, the liquid bridge evolution between the two drops was recorded, as were the maximal horizontal and vertical sweeping projections. Bridge evolution agreed well to a previous theoretical prediction, extending the parameter space. The sweeping droplet projections were used to benchmark numerical simulations of the coalescence process. The simulations were performed in OpenFOAM computational fluid dynamics framework. The OpenFOAM tool was modified to implement a simple boundary condition, which requires the mobility parameter M measured from experiment #1. Good agreement was found between numerics and experiments, validating the overall technique of measuring M in one context, and applying it in another to accurately predict complicated inertial-capillary processes, such as droplet coalescence.

Intellectual Merit: This project analyzes drop dynamics and new physics in the inertial spreading regime and matches it to a developed theory. This work validates a contact-line boundary condition numerically and uses it to extend previous theoretical predictions of liquid bridge evolution to a new parameter space. The validation of the contact-line mobility parameter against the data from the ISS reports that it is indeed a material parameter that can be measured and subsequently used to predict drop motions, for example, in the case of drop coalescence. More broadly, the project tells us that the mobility parameter can be used to predict conditions of liquid interface spreading under inertial regimes in other applications as well.

Broader Impact: Many medical, manufacturing, industrial, and agricultural processes operate in regimes of inertial spreading. Such operations and applications that will benefit from this work are additive manufacturing, immersion lithography, condensation heat transfer applications, and planar flow casting. Improved understanding of inertial spreading will lead to higher productivity, less waste, and more environmentally sustainable processes on Earth as well as better understanding of liquid spreading in Earth-nature and space-systems. Resonant droplet shapes and frequencies are predicted by a theory that solves a Schroedinger-like equation. This theory has striking parallels to the harmonic oscillator and to the periodic table as we know it from the arrangement of chemical elements. As such, under this project, an analogous “periodic table” of droplet shapes has been created and used for educational impact aimed at a broad group of students and the public to educate them about fluid physics in a manner that is engaging and inspiring.

 


Last Modified: 08/01/2022
Modified by: Susan Daniel
